thread.title: Some U.S.-funded programs help would-be migrants improve their lives and stay home
thread.title_full: Some U.S.-funded programs help would-be migrants improve their lives and stay home

author:
Tim Padgett 
WLRN-Miami Herald News
title: Some U.S.-funded programs help would-be migrants improve their lives and stay home
text:
Some U.S.-funded programs help would-be migrants improve their lives and stay home 
President Obama is asking Congress for $1 billion in new aid for Central America 
The money is to help support efforts to improve hardships that drive illegal immigration to the U.S. 
Violent gangs that control some slums count kids as young as 12 among their foot soldiers Christopher Estrada, 7, the nephew of David Estrada, looks out from the family home in San Pedro Sula, Honduras . David Estrada used to be a gang leader. He founded his neighborhood's unit of Honduras' most powerful street gang, MS-13, but is now employed and no longer with the gang. PATRICK FARRELL pfarrell@miamiherald.com A young boy fishes from a wooden pier in Lake Yojoa outside of San Pedro Sula, Honduras. PATRICK FARRELL pfarrell@miamiherald.com David Estrada, his daughter Fergie, 7, nephew Christopher Estrada, 7 and wife Odalys walk near their home in San Pedro Sula, Honduras. Estrada used to be a gang leader but now has a real job thanks to USAID job-training programs like METAS. PATRICK FARRELL pfarrell@miamiherald.com David Estrada near his home in San Pedro Sula, Honduras . Estrada used to be a gang leader for the violent MS-13, but now but now has a real job and is supporting his family thanks to USAID job-training programs like METAS. PATRICK FARRELL pfarrell@miamiherald.com Christopher Estrada, 7, the nephew, and Fergie Estrada, 7, the daughter of David Estrada, do homework and watch TV in their home in San Pedro Sula, Honduras. David Estrada used to be a gang leader but now has a real job thanks to USAID job-training programs like METAS. PATRICK FARRELL pfarrell@miamiherald.com Christopher Estrada, 7, the nephew, and Fergie Estrada, 7, the daughter of David Estrada, do homework and watch TV in their home in San Pedro Sula, Honduras. David Estrada used to be a gang leader but is now gainfully employed. PATRICK FARRELL pfarrell@miamiherald.com Fergie Estrada, 7, watches her father David Estrada work in the kitchen of their home in San Pedro Sula. Estrada used to be a gang leader for MS-13 but now has a real job thanks to USAID job-training programs like METAS. PATRICK FARRELL pfarrell@miamiherald.com PATRICK FARRELL pfarrell@miamiherald.com David Estrada (background) and his wife Odalys and daughter Fergie, 7, relax with relatives at their home in San Pedro Sula, Honduras. Estrada used to be a gang leader. He founded his neighborhood's unit of Honduras' most powerful street gang, MS-13, but is now gainfully employed. PATRICK FARRELL pfarrell@miamiherald.com Odalys Estrada, the wife of David Estrada makes Baleadas, a traditional Honduran dish, at her home in San Pedro Sula, Honduras. David Estrada used to be a gang leader but now has a real job thanks to USAID job-training programs like METAS. PATRICK FARRELL pfarrell@miamiherald.com David Estrada (center) works in a warehouse in San Pedro Sula, Honduras alongside co-worker Luis Rivas. Estrada used to be a gang leader for Honduras' most powerful street gang, MS-13. Now he works as a warehouse logistics manager thanks to USAID job-training programs like METAS. PATRICK FARRELL pfarrell@miamiherald.com David Estrada works in a warehouse logistics manager in San Pedro Sula, Honduras . Estrada used to be a gang leader for Honduras' most powerful street gang, MS-13. He was able to get job-training thanks to USAID programs like METAS. PATRICK FARRELL pfarrell@miamiherald.com Young men play pool in Santa Lucía, Honduras. PATRICK FARRELL pfarrell@miamiherald.com Jessel Recinos holds up his X-ray for Eduardo Varela, 13, at his parent's house in San Pedro Sula, Honduras. The X-ray shows a ghostly white spot where a bullet lodged just next to Recinos’ heart. Recinos runs a club in Cofradía Park called Skate Brothers. The club teaches kids to skateboard, rollerblade and stay clear of the dangerous street gangs. PATRICK FARRELL pfarrell@miamiherald.com Jessel Recinos teaches children to skate in Cofradía’s Park in San Pedro Sula, Honduras. Recinos runs a club called Skate Brothers, which teaches kids to skateboard, rollerblade and stay clear of the dangerous street gangs. He belongs to a club called Skate Brothers, which teaches kids to skateboard, rollerblade and stay clear of dangerous street gangs known as maras. Recinos runs a club called Skate Brothers, which teaches kids to skateboard, rollerblade and stay clear of dangerous street gangs known as maras. Recinos runs a club called Skate Brothers, which teaches kids to skateboard, rollerblade and stay clear of the dangerous maras street gangs. Recinos runs a club called Skate Brothers, which teaches kids to skateboard, rollerblade and stay clear of dangerous street gangs. PATRICK FARRELL pfarrell@miamiherald.com Jason Castejón, 14, plays Beethoven's Ode to Joy on a flute-like recorder at a new USAID youth outreach center at the San Martín outreach center in Tegucigalpa, Honduras. The center teaches skills to youth in an effort to keep them away from violent street gangs..
